author: JhoLow_1MDB
body:
STOP OVERTHINKING. BUY THE DIP. AMAT is bullish on the sustainability of semiconductor growth spurred by more than a current shortage of chips. **"This new wave is permanent," CFO Dan Durn says during the company's investor day**, *predicting Applied Materials's semiconductor sales should grow more than 60% through 2024*. Total revenue should rise from $17.2B in FY20 to $26.7B in FY24, with semiconductor sales rising from $11.4B to $18.4B, he says in presenting the base case of the company's outlook.


Can you get any more 🐂🐂🐂 than that?

author: BurlyNumNum
body:
Finally took the plunge - why didn’t I do this before?

Sold my first covered call today. MSFT. I’ve owned the stock for a long time. Settled on a strike price I’m comfortable with for 2023. Pocketed $4,000. 

And then I did three more for AMAT, CPB, and AAPL- I’m long in all so my cost basis is something I’m happy with if they get called away.

In less than 30 minutes, I made triple what I make at my regular job for a month.

Is this really real?

On the one hand, I’m amazed. Why did it take me this long to jump on board? On the other hand I can see how easy it could be for me to get carried away. To get too greedy.

author: ScarletHark
body:
A comment I was replying to was deleted, it was basically asking about different ways to play semis this summer on a budget, and mentioned they had done calls on SOXL and puts on SOXS so far. So I wanted to post the reply here anyway.

\---------------------------------------------------------------------------

SOXL/counter-SOXS is a good way to play the semi expansion through all of its phases; I have long SOXL in my investment account for this reason. It's 3x levered already, so adding leverage through options takes nerves of steel, because that leverage swings both directions -- you will need to ride out the stomach-churning drops that can happen day-to-day. However, swing-trading or scalping options on SOXL/SOXS can work, because the semi industry only has tailwinds right now, and at 1,000 feet, I think SOX/SOXL/counter-SOXS trends upwards through this year.

It's possible to do the same with individual names, including some of the ones I mentioned. One of the issues will be figuring out whether the recent gap-ups in names like AMAT, ASML, LRCX and TER are fully pricing in PEG, because AMAT jumped from 24x TTM earnings to 30x; TER jumped from about the same level to 27x; LRCX to 28x. But that's all TTM earnings -- these companies are expecting additional earnings growth this year on the back of announcements by Intel and TSMC to spend upwards of at least $120B over the next three years ($100B announced by TSMC, $20B so far announced by Intel, with a hint of more to come later this year). In Feb 2021, [the AMAT earnings release had already painted a rosy picture for 2021](https://www.fool.com/earnings/call-transcripts/2021/02/19/applied-materials-amat-q1-2021-earnings-call-trans/); we'll possibly know more come the [AMAT Investor Day on April 6](https://ir.appliedmaterials.com/events/event-details/investor-meeting). Also know that AMAT supplies not just the CPU/GPU manufacturers, but also has good exposure to the memory semiconductor manufacturers, such as Micron (MU), who just had an incredible ER and gave impressive 2021 projections.

I keep singling out AMAT because in terms of options, they are the most liquid, and therefore the most accessible; ASML and LRCX are great companies but their options chains tend to be less liquid than AMAT's; LRCX is a bit better than ASML's in this regard. These could be good LEAPS opportunities if you are willing to wait out IV before entering, and wait out buyers when you go to sell. TER only has monthlies, and have OK liquidity around the money, but you can still get decent action out to 0.04 delta above the money on TER calls. TER IVR is currently 11, but the options are still running in the 40s/50s for IV. 

I had previously done 113/114 put credit spreads on AMAT for Mar-5 and Mar-12 expirations, and those both held (Mar-5 closed at 113.45 IIRC, however). I later opened a PMCC on AMAT for Jan22\[80c\]/Mar-26\[121c\] and ended up chasing the short higher because AMAT jumped so fast (up to that point, AMAT had been trending steadily upwards, but not leaping like it has the past few days). I was able to get out of the short (which I had rolled to Apr-9 125) when AMAT retreated a bit, and then sold the LEAPS too because I figured the spike was done -- regretting that now. ;) I'm waiting a few more days to see if the churn is done (and for IV to come back down), and will probably open another LEAPS on it at some point. AMAT is still pretty volatile -- IVR 46 (which is unusual for them up to this point this year) and Apr-16 options are still in the 40s and 50s, favoring selling, rather than paying, premiums. 

I don't think we see a retreat in any of these names this summer; they've been able to withstand the rotation in and out of tech the past couple of weeks, which suggests that traders and investors are finally done painting everything that smells of tech with the same broad brush.

author: Defiant_Statement_81
body:
Dr. Burry can't be wrong on TSLA because the bubble hasn't burst yet. TSLA went from $200 to $880 in less than one year, if you think that this is how stocks normally behave than you are ignoring what's obvious. 

Take a look at any growth chart for any company and they're all the same, just like TSLA. From the time that any company went public until today each chart shows that the bulk of growth happened in the last year alone, evidence apparent before every crash or recession. Furthermore companies like AMAT saw a huge jump in the price just in the last month because of catalysts, not because of sales. More speculation just leads to higher and higher valuations not justified by revenue. It doesn't end well, it never has.

author: ThisPomelo4
body:
>ASML doesn't have EUV litho machines sitting in a warehouse waiting for someone to buy them, after all.

This is not true. If you check their earnings transcripts you can see that they talk about their deliveries as well as their inventory.

>For that reason, I believe that we're going to start seeing this revenue certainly inside 2021. At least, the execs at companies like AMAT seem to agree, and the market seems to be anticipating the PEG.

You're probably right about the latter part and perhaps wrong about the former part. AMAT isn't going to book profits in 2021 for the new capex outlay that was announced in the past couple of weeks from TSMC and Intel and the others. It would be accounting fraud. Even a nontrivial expansion of an existing fab will take 2-3y minimum. But the market is certainly anticipating the forward earnings. I am long-term bullish AMAT and the others, have been for a while, but AMAT is trading at a 33 P/E and INTC is trading at a 12.5 P/E. Assuming their earnings are correlated (which they ought to be if you normalize for lead/lag), I'd rather play the cheaper valuation with far cheaper IV.

Don't get me wrong, I so desperately want to be involved in the capex names but the entry point right now is mediocre. My thinking is that if they rip, they will carry the rest of the fab side of the sector with them. So I prefer the insanely cheap upside skew of INTC because it will rip if it can break through the psychological barrier that 65 represents for the spot price. My play is to wait for everything to get crushed in a correlation event later this summer and then scoop them up. The stars will have to align but I think they just might.

author: I_like_to_build
body:
Pick some shit you know, and watch it...  and stay in your lane:  for me MU, LRCX, NVDA, AMAT, AMD.

But also diversify a bit among sectors...  so I've got some DKNG, NCLH, CCL, DIS

Meme stocks are fine, but buy when cheap as fuck and with calls get them a bit out.  Some shit has stupid premiums.  Don't buy those.

When the market is doing great and everything is on fire, that's not the time to buy.  That's the time to unwind positions and take profits.

When shit sells off, you have you have to have a big pile of cash on hand to buy with.  If all your shit bled down during a sell off you can't buy the bottom.

Made a bunch of money on GME in March.  Then lost 20% of it because I was buying everything high.  Managed to get out as Nasdaq corrected down 10%.  But I had been watching all that shit.

When MU was around 80, LRCX was 550, AMAT 95... I bought a shit ton of calls cheap as fuck.  Same thing with the BB dip and cruise lines.

Then as it went up I started taking profits.

Did I sell AMAT and LRCX too soon.  Fuck yeah.  Did I buy back in.  Fuck no.  I'm not buying shit now.  I'm just taking profits.

When shit tanks back down I will buy calls again.  Am I missing out on shit.  Fuck yeah.  But my portfolio value is growing and I've got a ton of fucking ammo when prices come down.

Also once shit reaches 100%, I always sell half and cover my investment.  Now if it starts to sell off I'm good and can exit and still have gain overall.  I can also have the balls to let it moon because my risk is now zero.

author: TheoHornsby
body:
The underlying is always going to appreciate more than the options until option delta approaches 100.  

I would not buy to close the short calls at a loss because the market has a perverse way of making you pay for that (AMAT  reverses and you give up good gains on your long call).

The time to deal with the short call is before it gets ITM.  Roll up and out for a credit, giving yourself more upside potential for your long call and delaying assignment.  At $143 ($14 ITM), your short delta is very high and it's mostly intrinsic value.  There's not much that you can do with it at this point other than hope for a dip so that you can roll without having to sell a far dated month.

author: ZarrCon
body:
Commenting so I can look back in 5 years.

AMAT - Semiconductor supplier, demand for semiconductor related materials will only continue growing

BMY - Strong pipeline + Celgene acquisition diversifies their revenue streams, also trading at a reasonably cheap valuation

LMT - Military budget should remain stable regardless of which party controls the federal government, long-dated service contracts for platforms like F-35, also a play on space

UNH - Top 3 position in each of major health insurance markets: Commercial, Medicare Advantage (MA), and Medicaid. Any major changes to the current healthcare system would take years to execute and UNH would probably play a role in that transformation.

V - Continued digitization of financial system, pandemic recovery should be favorable to them, they also appear to be experimenting with crypto transactions for customers

Honorable Mention:

TSCO - Not quite as established as something like HD/LOW in terms of retail but higher upside potential, should be pretty resilient to e-commerce given the products they sell + their targeted market

author: HazardousMako
body:
This gapping up shit day after day makes more sense when you factor in the GME & Hwang debacles. 

Market makers and/or hedge funds are playing the game where they gotta pump the shit out of the overall market to increase their relative value vs the positions they still need to cover.

They are using the veneer of semiconductors for example, the fact that the demand / supply imbalance requires more semiconductors. That shit pumped AMAT for example 30% in matter of a week almost.

Take those profits, dump the silly stock on other people's heads and then use the profits to shore up, cover positions, and diversify their portfolio. They keep doing that until the game unravels, by GME's hand or another.

author: JayArlington
body:
For any interested in semiconductors, know that the industry is comprised of the following:

-Integrated Chip manufacturers (both design and produce chips): Intel

-Outsource Chip manufacturers (produce chips designed by others): TSMC, Samsung

-Dedicated Chip Designers (design chips but let others manufacture them): Nvdia, AMD, Qualcomm 

-Semiconductor Equipment Manufacturers (design the equipment and services used to produce chips): ASML, Lam Research, Applied Materials

For the next year or so, I bet the Equipment Manufacturers are the ones that do the best.
